pros: the best boss you will ever have, flexible, extensive free training, great colleuges, interesting work.
cons: A messy job that you’ll want a change of clothes for.

review_title: Good on paper, but look eslsewhere.
pros: Benefits, engaged student body, pay, colleagues
cons:
On paper values are good, in practice they are non existent. Students and staff often will not hear back from senior leaders regarding questions or concerns on policy changes. Decisions are often made without consulting those that actually do the work. Often these decisions are badly thought out and lead to negative impacts on students and staff.  You are told to just do it and have no context to explain to frustrated students. Student life staff have been told numerous times individually and as teams to “stop pushing back on decisions that leadership make”.  Our jobs are to advocate for students but it is harder to do that effectively. 

You are treated as if your experience and education do not matter. Reed, especially student life, sells themselves to potential employees and students as a progressive forward thinking institution. That was what Reed was. That is no longer the case. This will often be confirmed by students. Policies are being made that simply copy and paste failed and harmful policies from other institutions with little regard to those the decisions impact. There is no creative thinking or doing things differently anymore. You’ll be pushed out if you start to push back or labeled as problematic. No benefits or pay is worth having your voice continually silenced. Take your talents elsewhere (look outside higher education) and save your mental health.

pros: The campus is beautiful, the students are really wonderful, some of the benefits are good.
cons: The administration doesn't seem to have a vision, and HR is profoundly unhelpful. It's part of a longer-term pattern, but it's just not improving and if anything seems to be getting worse. Staff are not treated well and turnover is really high. I would definitely stay for a long time, but not with the way admin treat staff anymore. It used to be about a mission, but now it's just the paycheck, and it's not a very good one at that.

review_title: Great benefits, beautiful place to work
pros: There are lots of very smart and intelligent people working here that are passionate about what they do.
cons: There is some resistance to change- especially from those who have been at Reed for a long time.

pros: Job security, tons of experience, working on a beautiful campus, student body is amazing and the alumni are super involved
cons: Leadership can be secretive and make campus/culture-altering decisions without notice

pros: Flexible hours for this job position.
cons: Uncompensated preparation required for this position.

pros: Lots of vacation and holidays off
cons: Low pay job with high requirements

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Portland, OR
pros: Nice campus, kind atmosphere, engaged students.
cons: Non-transparent review and hiring practices. Faculty outside of one's department and division make decisions with no mechanisms for feedback. Not focused on retaining or promoting visiting faculty. Students can often be high-strung.

pros: great benefits and they hire incredible co-workers
cons: distinct lack of clear leadership, no documentation

job_title: Student Phonathon Caller in Portland, OR
pros: Decent bosses/culture, great work/life balance, choose your own hours, and you get the opportunity to network.
cons: Does not pay a living wage, which is entirely doable considering the benefits student callers provide.

job_title: Peer Career Advisor in Portland, OR
pros:
Great Team
Solid pay
Support from peers and superiors
cons: Challenge to balance school and work

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: Supportive mentors, usually good opportunities to advocate for students
cons: Very bad retention rate for people of color

job_title: Environmental Health and Safety Officer in Portland, OR
pros: Pretty good, can work on the computer or can walk around campus checking fire alarms and stuff
cons: Kind of boring and not what I personally want to do with my life

job_title: Chemistry Research Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Positive learning environment, it was fine.
cons: Low pay, temporary, it was fine

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: working at the library as a student employee was a great way to balance making money and keeping up with schoolwork. great community and culture.
cons: not really any, I loved my job

job_title: Zebrafish Care Technician in Portland, OR
pros: This position is a collaborative, engaging, and extremely rewarding one. I always look forward to coming into the lab for my animal husbandry experience. In particular, I find that watching the zebrafish grow for the genetics lab is something that is not only interesting, but also very satisfying. You always have visual evidence that you are doing your job correctly!
cons: There are times in the lab when there are some challenges, such as rotifers that we usually feed the fish crashing, or a lot of fish that need to be culled. This is obviously the nature of working in such a lab, but it can sometimes be difficult to watch these things happen.

job_title: Student Body Vice President in Portland, OR
pros:
- Student autonomy
- Great amount of experience for position
- Loads of responsibility
cons:
- Have to fix a lot of the administrations shortcomings
- Working with peers can sometimes be a bit difficult
- Lack of direct communication with student body at times (lack of representation)

job_title: Math Peer Tutor in Portland, OR
pros: Experience, transparency, giving back to the community
cons: Have to market yourself for individual tutoring hours

pros: great community that will teach you
cons: Nothing is negative, no improvements can be suggested

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: I learned how to lead discussions
cons: Hard to balance being a student and student work

pros: Worked independently for the most part.
cons: Sometimes switch in staff made small problems.

pros: Very flexible work schedule, great for students!
cons: Nothing much that I would change!

review_title: Horrible! Reed's HR department creates an environment where bulling flourishes
pros: Pay and benefits are good. If you don't want to work you'll like it at Reed as there is no accountability for attendance or quantity of work.
cons: Reed is plagued by a significant drug environment where the college administration turns a blind eye to under age alcohol consumption, drug use, drug dealing, and sexual assaults of staff and students. The college won't tell the parents of a minor student when they become the victim of a sex crime and won't report it to police either unless the student wants these reports to occur. The school portrays itself as open to diversity, but actually they discourage conservative views of employees. The school has an atmosphere that fosters bullying of staff. If a student complains, or multiple students, or multiple staff gang up on someone of conservative background the HR director will look into the matter, believe the group complaining without other evidence, and move to terminate the employee despite the only thing they have done is try to maintain accountability and honesty.

review_title: The campus is nice, students are great but management is lacking.
job_title: Community Safety Officer in Portland, OR
pros: The campus is beautiful! You can truly find a nice quiet place to relax on the campus. The students (most of them) are exceptional. The students are friendly and respectful.
cons: Management is lacking. Human resources, like most HR's, is lacking and not there for the employee. They treat employees poorly and could care less about what is really going on. The lack of good values within the department I worked for was a huge negative. Most of the people I worked with wanted to sit around and do nothing all day/night. A lot of employees leaving reviews will say it was a good place to work but that is most likely based on not having to really work. Most of the employees are on the lazy side but management allows it.

pros: The students are driving the institution toward a more equitable expression of itself. You will likely experience the most intelligent and thoughtful coworkers you've ever had. The benefits are second to none and the campus is beautiful. Campus culture, broadly speaking, embraces gender diversity and non-binary identities though this trait is not uniform within all offices.
cons: The administration protects leaders and managers who are toxic and harmful. Even at the associate level, the expectation is that employees will be at-attention 7 days a week. The stress level for administrative staff is high at all observed ranks. The atmosphere can be somewhat litigious and prone to politics, even for a higher ed institution. While I do believe the college has the best intentions in moving toward racial justice, it has yet to make the necessary changes to prove its commitment to equity and inclusion.

pros: I can't say enough good things about the student worker positions at the Office of Residence Life. The department is very supportive and very open to initiatives. There's a lot of flexibility built into the position so you can pick up and create projects that appeal to your interests. There are opportunities for increased responsibility and wage raises for those who seek them.
cons: Relative to the rest of campus, the location is a bit out of the way. Like any front desk position, there may be some interaction with disgruntled persons, but this is generally limited to a few brief, key periods during the year and the upper management is usually more than willing to handle these calls.

pros: Working at Reed can be great in that student workers often have a fair amount of autonomy and are trusted to do jobs that have a high amount of responsibility. Additionally, I have found that usually there is a high degree of flexibility in scheduling.
cons: On the other hand, sometimes I feel that Reed expects too much out of student workers and doesn't give them the support and resources that are necessary to succeed.  This is not to say that the administration should micro-manage students, only that students in certain positions can't be successful unless members of the administration work with them to achieve shared goals.

job_title: Community Safety Officer in Portland, OR
pros: Reed is an amazing academic institution! You will work with a wonderful assortment of well educated people.
cons: The Community Safety Department's management , in particular,  is more concerned with hiding in their office's and avoiding all forms of work and accountability. In a department of 15 officers there are 7 managers/administrators, nearly 1 manager for every 2 officers, yet we have officers working alone while in charge of the safety of over 2000 students, faculty and staff. The disregard to safety and amount of money wasted by Community Safety Managers is REPREHENSIBLE.

review_title: Overall, really good place to work
pros: Great benefits, including generous vacation policy, good health insurance options, and less common benefits like inexpensive lunchtime exercise classes, the opportunity to take academic classes, and on campus events. Most of the people I worked with at Reed were considerate and good at their jobs. My favorite part of working at Reed was working with Reed students.
cons: In my experience, the salaries are not competitive, especially for recent Reed graduates (even in comparison to other recent graduates). The use of recent Reed graduates who are already devoted to Reed for cheap labor seems vaguely predatory.

pros: Had to get up early to set up lectures, which lets you catch up on waking up before morning classes. Generally not too stressful, and when it gets bad you just get to ask for help from someone who really knows what they're doing. Definitely recommend.
cons: Professors expect the AV to work so when something goes wrong it can get a little stressful but if you keep your cool it's not so bad.

review_title: Reed College Underpays and Undervalues their staff and faculty of color
pros: The other staff and faculty of color are amazing to work with, very collaborative
cons: Reed as an institution promotes diversity and inclusion but does not actively work to make sure those things are being implemented towards their black and brown students, staff, and faculty. They underpay and undervalue their staff and faculty of color by giving them more work than what they are paid for and creating hostile working enviornments.

pros: you can work on homework on the job and there's usually snacks
cons: Students are treated like corporate drones instead of Reedies. Managers generally are not able to answer questions. Scheduling is not very flexible. Hours get reduced in the spring time and the call center is overbooked so sometimes you are sent home for no reason. Commission is so small it might as well not exist. Even though you can work on homework it's impossible to get anything done because the call center is so loud and you have to make phone calls at the same time. The snacks are not very good.

pros:
- Understanding of difficult schedules
- Great skill building, training
- Kind and skilled management
- Good coworkers
cons:
- DIfficult with classwork
- Can't work over 20 hours/week during the school year
- Not all jobs offer summer work
- Experiences may vary across departments/positions

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Very flexible, fun workplace! Good culture and great people to work with.
cons: Not much that I can think of, shelving books can be no fun but someone has to do it. Even with menial tasks like book shelving supervisors are very reasonable and try to shuffle work around so no one works for too long on strenuous stuff.

pros: I love the benefits package, my colleagues are great people, the campus is lovely, it is a very short commute from my home.
cons: The salaries are low, but mostly balanced out by the other great things about working here.  This is mostly a wonderful place to work.

pros: Employers and employees really believe in the work that they are doing. A warm environment between faculty, staff, and students.
cons: More frequent hours each week would be ideal. More regular hours each week would also be ideal.

job_title: Assistant Dean of Admission in Portland, OR
pros: A lot of vacation days in benefits package, good health and retirement contribution.
cons: Management is ineffective and wishy-washy. Little opportunity to take vacation, a lot of last-minute assigned nights and weekends with little planning or consideration of employees. Though promotion exists in title, it doesn't benefit employees because management micro-manages.

pros: Great culture, friendly people, good opportunities for young professionals (especially current students and recent graduates).
cons: Poor management; little trust of lower employees. Things change often and don't always get effectively communicated to the whole office.

pros:
It's a fun student culture to be around.
Generally supported as an employee.
Access to gym and pool.
The president is accessible and generally amicable!
cons:
Training could have been more extensive.
Can always work on diversity.
Can't check out equipment..
Always a lot of work to do! 10+ hour days sometimes.

review_title: great place to be a nurse
pros: working with students, flexible schedule, variety of responsibilities, collaboration with other departments on campus, great benefits
cons: pay is lower compared to other nursing jobs, higher education politics

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Portland, OR
pros: They treat visitors like tenure-track faculty. Put you up in faculty housing at a below market rate, pay your utilities. The students are amazing. You're left to teach.
cons: As a visitor, you have to leave.

pros: Supportive work atmosphere, good experience for psychotherapy, decent benefits. Also a unique place to work with interesting populations.
cons: Pay is not very high, but pretty standard for college counseling center positions.

pros: As a research assistant you get paid  a lot without doing much; plus it looks great on a resume
cons: It can be pretty boring. But again, it's pretty good for what you are paid, at least in the economics department.

pros: Great students, wonderful staff, best paying job on campus!
cons: Lots of meeting, they seem gratuitous and cater to a low level of experience.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Pretty good working environment and friendly manager and students to work with.
cons: you have to talk to a lot of people if you think it's a con.

pros: Reed does a terrific job supporting its staff.
cons: As with any job, Reed is not immune to interpersonal conflicts, but that is to be expected.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: Many job opportunities within the department for students.
cons: No cons really. Great faculty to work with.

pros: Fast paced environment where you will learn a lot!

pros: Great place to learn college admissions

pros: Benefits, Catering Often, Great People

pros: Fantastic education and fantastic people.
cons: A bit small - a bubble.

pros: Great learning experience, good pay
